clinical_study.brief_title: Study of Smoking Trajectory in Newly Diagnosis Lung Cancer Patients
clinical_study.official_title: Smoking Trajectory in Newly Diagnosis Lung Cancer Patients

brief_summary.textblock:
1. Understanding the smoking change patterns among the newly diagnosis lung cancer patients after cancer diagnosis.
2. Explore the related factors of the smoking change patterns.
3. The type of smoking trajectory impact on survival and quality of life.

detailed_description.textblock: This was a prospective longitudinal design study. The investigators used the structure questionnaires to collect the data from a consecutive sample of newly diagnosed lung cancer patients.

primary_outcome.measure: Changes From Baseline Smoking Behavior at 1,2,3,4,5,6 Months
primary_outcome.description: Self-reported smoking during the last 30 days was a dichotomous variable.

secondary_outcome.measure: Changes From Baseline Quality of Life at 1,2,3,4,5,6 Months
secondary_outcome.description: Functional Assessment of Cancer Therapy-Lung, Version 4 (FACT-L v. 4) was a 36-item ordinal scale, five-point scale from 0 (not at all) to 4 (very much). There were 5 domains: Physical, social/family, emotional, and functional well-being; lung cancer subscale (symptoms, cognitive function, regret of smoking). Subscale scores added to obtain total score, with higher scores indicating better quality of life.

secondary_outcome.measure: Proportion of participants with Overall Survival up to 2 years
secondary_outcome.time_frame: follow up to one or two years

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Over 20 years old
- Newly diagnosed lung cancer
- Conscious clear and able to communicate
- Agreed to participate the study
Exclusion Criteria:
- Consciously confused
- Cognitive or psychotic disorders
